headline.main: A Reading List for a Troubled Land

lead_paragraph: Afghanistan, for centuries a country of brutal wars between local tribes and foreign armies, has inspired a substantial literature, fiction and nonfiction, military history and semicomic fantasy. Probably the most famous literary work is Rudyard Kipling's classic story ''The Man Who Would be King,'' about two British charlatans, Peachey Carnehan and Danny Dravot, who go to the lawless fictional province of Kafiristan with a plan to turn it into their personal kingdom.
abstract: Descriptions of some books on Afghanistan, including fiction, nonfiction, military history and semicomic fantasy (M)
